ANTI-SMOKING CAMPAIGNS HAVE REDUCED SMOKING, AUSTRALIAN STUDY SHOWS
CANBERRA, APRIL 27 (XINHUA) - A NEW AUSTRALIAN STUDY HAS PROVIDED EVIDENCE THAT MASS MEDIA ANTI-SMOKING CAMPAIGNS ARE CAPABLE OF SIGNIFICANTLY CUTTING THE PREVALENCE OF SMOKING IN THE COMMUNITY, THE AUSTRALIAN NEWSPAPER PUBLISHED IN MELBOURNE, THE "AGE" SAID TODAY.
THE STUDY FOUND THAT SMOKING LEVELS IN THE AUSTRALIAN BIG CITIES SUCH AS MELBOURNE AND SYDNEY, DECLINED SIGNIFICANTLY FOLLOWING THE INTRODUCTION OF MEDIA CAMPAIGNS IN THE EARLY TO MID 1980'S WARNING OF THE DANGERS OF SMOKING.
THE FINDINGS ARE REGARDED BY INTERNATIONAL CANCER EXPERTS AS CRUCIAL IN THE GLOBAL FIGHT AGAINST TOBACCO-RELATED DEATHS AND ILLNESS, THE PAPER NOTED.
THE STUDY, WHICH IS TO BE PUBLISHED IN THE AMERICAN JOURNAL OF PUBLIC HEALTH, WAS CARRIED BY RESEARCHERS IN THE DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC HEALTH AT THE UNIVERSITY OF NEW SOUTH WALES, AND IN THE CENTER FOR BEHAVIORAL RESEARCH IN CANCER IN CARLTON.
A RESEARCHER, DR. DAVID HILL, OF THE CENTER OF BEHAVIORAL RESEARCH IN CANCER, SAID THAT THE DROP IN SMOKING LEVELS IN VICTORIA SINCE THE CAMPAIGNS BEGAN IN 1985 WOULD MEAN ABOUT 420 FEWER DEATHS IN THE STATE EACH YEAR.
THE FINDINGS ALSO SUGGESTED THAT ABOUT 30,000 FEWER VICTORIANS HAD TAKEN UP SMOKING SINCE THE CAMPAIGNS BEGAN -- ABOUT 88,500 MEN AND 40,000 WOMEN.
Copyright INDUSTRIAL HEALTH & HAZARDS UPDATE da NewsNet May 1990
CIGARETTE SMOKE-INDUCED DNA ADDUCTS FORMED IN THE LUNG, NASAL MUCOSA, AND LIVER OF RATS
The formation of DNA adducts in the nasal, lung, and liver tissues of rats exposed to fresh cigarette smoke for up to 40 weeks is reported and examined (by Baylor College of Medicine). The amount of smoke total particulate matter (TPM) inhaled and the blood carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) values averaged 5-5.5 mg smoke TPM/day/rat, and 5.5%, respectively. The pulmonary AHH activity measured at the termination of each experiment showed an average increase of two- to threefold in smoke-exposed

The formation of DNA adducts in the nasal, lung, and liver tissues of rats exposed to fresh cigarette smoke for up to 40 weeks is reported and examined (by Baylor College of Medicine).
